history.short_description: An ancient Vishnu temple where the deity is worshipped in the reclining posture on serpent Anantha (Adi Sesha), historically associated with the Travancore royal family.
history.detailed: Sree Padmanabhaswamy Temple is one of the most revered temples in South India, dedicated to Lord Vishnu in the reclining posture on the serpent Anantha (Adi Sesha). The origins of the temple are considered to be lost in antiquity, with references found in ancient texts and traditions. In 1750, Maharaja Marthanda Varma of Travancore dedicated his kingdom to Lord Padmanabha, ruling thereafter as the 'Padmanabha Dasa' (servant of the Lord). The temple is built in a blend of Kerala and Dravidian architectural styles, with an impressive gopuram, intricate stone and wood carvings, and a sacred tank. It gained worldwide attention in recent years when its underground vaults were opened, revealing an enormous collection of treasures and artifacts.

significance.religious: One of the 108 Divya Desams (holy abodes of Lord Vishnu) and the presiding deity of the erstwhile Travancore royal family. It is an important pilgrimage centre for Vaishnavites and Hindus across the world.
significance.cultural: A major symbol of Kerala’s heritage, architecture, and classical temple traditions. The temple complex and East Fort area are important cultural zones of Thiruvananthapuram.
significance.tourism: A must-visit attraction in Thiruvananthapuram, known for its architecture, spiritual ambience, and historical stories connected to the Travancore kingdom and the temple treasures.

timings.note: Very early darshan; recommended for devotees wanting less crowd.
Closing time may vary slightly on special days.
Darshan timings can change during festivals; visitors should re-check.

entry_rules.additional_notes: All electronic devices and cameras are typically not allowed inside the temple. Lockers may be available near the entrance.

men.required: Mundu/dhoti tied around the waist. Upper body bare or with traditional angavastram.
men.tips: Dhoti can usually be rented or bought near the temple entrance.

women.required: Saree, mundum-neriyathum, or long skirt with blouse.
women.not_allowed: Jeans, leggings with short tops, western dresses, shorts.
women.tips: Shawls or overwraps may be used to adjust to the dress code if needed.

entry_fee.special_darshan: Paid special/quick darshan tickets may be available at temple counters (price varies).

best_time_to_visit: Early morning for peaceful darshan and less crowd.
Weekdays are generally less crowded than weekends and festival days.
visitor_info.average_crowd_level: High during weekends, festivals, and evenings; moderate on weekday mornings.

common_complaints: Strict dress code can be inconvenient for unprepared visitors.
Limited parking space during rush hours.
tips_from_visitors: Reach early in the morning for quicker darshan.
Carry or buy appropriate traditional clothing nearby.
Keep valuables safely and avoid carrying bulky bags.

by_road.description: Well connected by KSRTC and private buses from various parts of the city and nearby towns.
by_road.parking_info: Limited parking available around East Fort area; can get very crowded during peak temple hours and festivals.

local_transport_tips: Use auto-rickshaws or app-based cabs for flexible and quick access.
Plan extra time for traffic, especially in the evenings and festival days.

nearby_food_places.name: Garden Grille & Bar
nearby_food_places.location_note: Hilton Garden Inn, near Pattom Road

recommended_itineraries: Morning: Sree Padmanabhaswamy Temple → Breakfast at nearby vegetarian restaurant → Napier Museum & Zoo.
Evening: Temple darshan → Local shopping around East Fort → Sunset at Shanghumugham Beach.
alerts_suggestions: Show festival alerts (e.g., special pujas, processions) which may affect timings and traffic.
Highlight dress code reminder before visitor navigates to the temple.
Provide live or user-updated crowd status if you add that feature later.

meta.data_note: Timings and rules may change on special days and festivals; visitors should verify before visiting.
